title: Integrate Gradio interface with Dash app
description:
IMPLEMENTATION PLAN:

1. Remove obsolete code:

   - Delete data/ai_assistant/model_manager.py, response_generator.py, context_builder.py, prompt_templates.py
   - Keep data/ai_assistant/chat_persistence.py (for future use)
   - Delete ui/ai_assistant.py (old Dash UI components)

2. Create new Gradio integration:

   - Style matching: Use app colors, same position as app-notifications (top: 10px, right: 10px)

Technical decisions:
- Use iframe (not separate window) for seamless UX
- Gradio server auto-starts on first button click (lazy loading)
- Panel component: dbc.Offcanvas with custom positioning
- Communication: None needed (Gradio is self-contained)
- Styling: Match dashboard theme with custom CSS

title: Create AI chatbot callbacks for panel control
description:
Create callbacks to manage chatbot panel state:

NEW FILE: callbacks/ai_chatbot.py

CALLBACKS:

1. toggle_chatbot_panel() - Open/close panel
   Input: 'ai-assistant-button' n_clicks
   Input: 'ai-chatbot-close' n_clicks
   State: 'ai-chatbot-state' data (is_open, is_minimized)
   Output: 'ai-chatbot-panel' style (display, height)
   Output: 'ai-chatbot-state' data (updated state)
   
   Logic:
   - First click: Start Gradio server (via GradioServerManager)
   - Show panel with loading state
   - Health check Gradio (retry 3x with 1s delay)
   - When ready: Update iframe src
   - Close: Hide panel (keep server running)

2. minimize_chatbot_panel() - Minimize/maximize
   Input: 'ai-chatbot-minimize' n_clicks
   State: 'ai-chatbot-state' data
   Output: 'ai-chatbot-panel' style (height)
   Output: 'ai-chatbot-minimize' children (icon switch)
   Output: 'ai-chatbot-state' data
   
   Logic:
   - Toggle between 50px (minimized) and 650px (expanded)
   - Switch icon: fa-minus ↔ fa-expand-alt

3. chatbot_iframe_status() - Update iframe based on server status
   Input: Interval component (every 5s, only when panel open)
   State: 'ai-chatbot-state' data
   Output: 'ai-chatbot-iframe-container' children
   
   Logic:
   - Check if Gradio server is running
   - If running: Show iframe
   - If not running: Show error message + retry button

STORES:
- ai-chatbot-state: {is_open: bool, is_minimized: bool, server_ready: bool}

ERROR HANDLING:
- Log all server communication failures
- Show user-friendly error messages
- Provide manual retry button

title: Enhance active query visual indicator in Queries tab
description:
Users have difficulty identifying which query is currently active and when its data was last updated.

## Current State
- Active indicator: '(Active)' text postfix attached to query name in dropdown
- No visibility into when data was last refreshed
- Users must manually track when they last updated data

## Problem
Users need to quickly identify:
1. Which query is currently active
2. When was the data last updated (important for stale data awareness)

## Solution: Compact Relative Timestamp Display
Add last update timestamp after [Active] postfix using compact relative format:

**Format**: Query Name [Active] • 2h ago

**Examples**:
- Last 12 Weeks [Active] • 2h ago
- Development Sprint • 5d ago
- Bugs Query [Active] • Just now
- Old Query • Jan 28

**Relative time ranges**:
- Just now (< 1 minute)
- 5m ago (1-59 minutes)
- 2h ago (1-23 hours)
- 3d ago (1-6 days)
- 2w ago (7-28 days)
- Jan 15 (>28 days, same year)
- Dec '25 (previous years)

**Timestamp Source**:
- Use jira_cache.created_at from database
- Represents START of update operation (when data snapshot begins)
- Only shown for queries with fetched data (never-fetched queries show no timestamp)

## Implementation Scope
1. Add get_relative_time_string() helper in data/query_manager.py
2. Enhance list_queries_with_last_update() to join with jira_cache.created_at
3. Update dropdown rendering in 13 files (ui/query_selector.py, callbacks/*, etc.)
4. Add mobile CSS for graceful text wrapping on small screens
5. Add unit tests for relative time formatting

## Mobile Considerations
- **Character budget**: ~10-12 chars added per query name
- **320px screens**: Text wraps gracefully to 2 lines (CSS word-wrap)
- **Responsive font**: 13px on <375px screens for better fit
- **Visual separator**: Bullet (•) creates clear hierarchy
- **No icon fallback needed**: Testing will confirm

## Goals
- Instant awareness of data freshness
- Compact display that works on mobile (320px+)
- Intuitive relative time format
- No timestamp for never-fetched queries
notes: Implemented Option 1: Compact relative time display in query dropdowns. Timestamps show after [Active] postfix using format '• 2h ago' or '• Jan 28'. Created time_formatting.py utility, updated 13+ files, added mobile CSS, and created 18 unit tests (all passing). Timestamp represents operation START time from jira_cache.created_at.

title: Page not auto-refreshing after update - footer and toast only appear after manual refresh
description: After update from 2.7.16 to 2.7.17, the overlay disappears correctly but the page does NOT auto-refresh. Footer version and success toast only appear after manual browser refresh. Expected: page should auto-refresh or Dash should auto-reconnect and trigger UI updates.
notes:
INVESTIGATION FINDINGS:

**Current Behavior:**
1. User clicks Update button
2. Overlay shows 'Reconnecting...'
3. Update completes, overlay disappears
4. Page stays on old version (footer still shows v2.7.16)
5. No success toast shown
6. Manual refresh → footer updates to v2.7.17 + success toast appears

**Expected Behavior:**
1. User clicks Update button
2. Overlay shows
3. Update completes
4. Overlay disappears
5. Page auto-refreshes OR Dash auto-reconnects
6. Footer shows v2.7.17
7. Success toast displays immediately

**TIMING-DEPENDENT BEHAVIOR (Critical Finding):**

Test 1 - Fast Machine (original report):
- Toast: NOT shown
- Footer: NOT updated
- After manual refresh: Both toast and footer appear

Test 2 - Slow Machine:
- Toast: SHOWN correctly
- Footer: NOT updated
- After manual refresh: Footer updates, toast does NOT show again (correct)

**Analysis:**
This confirms a RACE CONDITION between JavaScript DOM manipulation and Dash reconnection:
- JavaScript tries to update footer + show toast (lines 293-310)
- Dash websocket reconnects and re-renders components
- On fast machines: Dash reconnects before JavaScript executes → both fail
- On slow machines: JavaScript toast succeeds, but Dash still overwrites footer before it can update

**Root Cause:**
The code removes the overlay (line 293) which allows Dash to begin reconnection. Dash then re-renders the entire page/components, OVERWRITING any JavaScript DOM changes made between overlay removal and full reconnection.

The JavaScript manipulations (footer update, toast creation) are fighting against Dash's component re-rendering. They only work if executed after Dash finishes reconnecting, which is unpredictable timing.

**Code Location:**
- assets/update_reconnect.js lines 270-330 (pollServer function, update flow branch)
- Line 293: hideReconnectingOverlay() removes overlay → TRIGGERS Dash reconnection
- Line 295-303: Updates footer via DOM manipulation (RACES with Dash re-render)
- Line 306: Shows toast via DOM manipulation (RACES with Dash re-render)
- Line 309: Sets isUpdateFlow = false
- MISSING: No coordination with Dash reconnection state

**Why Manual Refresh Works:**
Manual refresh causes browser to:
1. Re-request page from server (gets new v2.7.17 HTML)
2. Re-initialize Dash with new version
3. Check post_update flag in /api/version (lines 541-577)
4. Show success toast via init() function (line 569) AFTER Dash initializes
5. Footer already rendered with correct version in HTML

**Solution Options:**

Option A: Force page reload after overlay removal (simplest, RECOMMENDED)
- Add window.location.reload() after line 309
- Pros: Guarantees fresh page load with new version, no race conditions
- Cons: Full page reload (brief white flash) - but expected after update
- Implementation: One line change

Option B: Wait for Dash reconnection before DOM updates
- Monitor Dash's connection state (window.dash_clientside?)
- Only update footer + show toast AFTER Dash finishes reconnecting
- Pros: No page reload
- Cons: Complex, fragile, requires Dash internals knowledge

Option C: Use post_update flag mechanism (current fallback path)
- Remove all DOM manipulation from update flow (lines 295-310)
- Let init() function (lines 541-577) handle everything on page load
- Force reload after overlay removal to trigger init() path
- Pros: Uses existing reliable code path
- Cons: Requires page reload anyway

**Recommendation:** Option A (force reload) or Option C (which is essentially Option A + code cleanup). Page reload after update is acceptable UX and eliminates all race conditions. Users EXPECT a 'fresh start' after update.

**Proposed Fix:**
`javascript
// Line 293: Remove overlay
hideReconnectingOverlay();

// IMMEDIATELY force page reload to trigger clean initialization
// This uses the post_update flag mechanism (lines 541-577)
// which reliably shows toast + updates footer after Dash initializes
window.location.reload();

// Remove lines 295-310 (DOM manipulation that races with Dash)
`

**Test Case:**
1. Start app v2.7.16
2. Check for updates (should show v2.7.17 available)
3. Click Update button
4. Wait for overlay to appear → disappear
5. VERIFY: Page reloads automatically (brief white flash acceptable)
6. VERIFY: Footer shows v2.7.17 immediately after reload
7. VERIFY: Success toast appears immediately after reload
8. VERIFY: No duplicate toasts or broken state
9. TEST ON BOTH: Fast machine AND slow machine (timing must be consistent)

title: Optimize data load and add loading spinner for large datasets
description:
Goal: Improve performance of data loading after query update, query change, or data points slider adjustment (especially for large datasets). If loading takes >1s, show a visually themed spinner at the best UX location.

Research notes:
- Current load time can reach 5s on large datasets.
- Spinner should be non-intrusive, thematically fit the app, and only appear if load >1s.
- Optimize backend and/or frontend for faster data delivery.
- Consider async loading, caching, and UI feedback best practices.
- Do not implement yet; this bead is for future release planning.

References: User request 2026-01-27, Copilot research.
notes:
## Investigation: Staggered Loading Issue

### Problem Identified
1. Spinner works on initial load ✓
2. NO spinner during updates (slider, query changes) ✗
3. Page elements load one-by-one (jarring UX) ✗

### Root Cause
The render_tab_content callback has **cache optimization** that makes it return almost instantly when data hasn't changed. The callback flow:
1. User moves slider → triggers callback
2. Callback checks cache → finds match → returns immediately (<100ms)
3. 300ms delay prevents spinner from showing
4. BUT: Plotly charts inside the content render asynchronously afterward
5. Result: No loading indicator, then charts pop in one by one

### Why dcc.Loading Doesn't Help
- dcc.Loading only shows during *callback execution*
- Callback executes instantly (returns cached content)
- Chart rendering happens *after* callback completes (client-side)
- Loading component thinks work is done, but charts still rendering

### Potential Solutions
1. **Reduce delay_show to 100ms** - catch more updates but risk flash
2. **Add skeleton loaders** - show placeholder charts before Plotly renders
3. **Disable caching temporarily** - force callback to be slower (bad for perf)
4. **Client-side loading detection** - detect Plotly render events
5. **Pre-render charts** - generate chart JSON before returning (slowdown accepted)

### Recommendation
Need to balance performance (caching) vs UX (loading indicators). Current caching makes app FAST but loading INVISIBLE.
close_reason: Implemented visual feedback via sticky banner icons - purple fade for UI operations, orange spinner for Update Data

FINDINGS:

**Expected Flow (Update Data)**:
1. callbacks/settings/data_update.py → _start_background_sync()
2. data/jira/scope_sync.py → sync_jira_scope_and_data():
   - Fetches JIRA issues (with delta optimization)

3. callbacks/settings/metrics.py → auto_calculate_metrics_after_fetch()

- Removed fetch from weekly_calculator.py (CORRECT)

**Root Cause Hypothesis**:
The fetch is happening at step 2 (sync_jira_scope_and_data) which is CORRECT. User's complaint suggests:
1. Maybe changelog fetch in sync_jira_scope_and_data is slow/buggy
2. Maybe SQLite refactoring broke database operations
3. Maybe delta fetch isn't working (fetching all 324 issues every time)

**Next Steps**:
1. Test Update Data and examine logs
2. Verify changelog is saved to database correctly
3. Verify delta fetch works (only changed issues)

title: Browser opens new window on every app launch instead of checking for existing tabs
description: After update completes and app restarts normally, every subsequent app launch opens a new browser window/tab instead of detecting existing tabs at http://127.0.0.1:8050. Expected: App should detect if browser tab already exists before launching new one. Actual: webbrowser.open(url, new=2) always opens new tab. Root cause: Python webbrowser module has no API to check for existing tabs. Potential solutions: 1) Add JavaScript-based heartbeat to detect connected clients, 2) Check for active WebSocket connections before launching, 3) Add startup flag --no-browser for manual control, 4) Accept current behavior as limitation of webbrowser module.
notes:
DECISION: AS DESIGNED - NOT A BUG

**User Expectation Analysis**:
When user double-clicks BurndownChart.exe:
- Expected: Browser opens immediately (visual confirmation app started)
- Actual: Browser opens ✅
- This is CORRECT behavior

**Why This Makes Sense**:
1. User has no way to know if app started without browser opening
2. Terminal window might be hidden/minimized
3. System tray icon might not be noticed immediately
4. Opening browser = clear visual feedback that app is running

**Update Scenario is Different**:
- User KNOWS app is running (existing tab open)
- update_reconnect.js handles reconnection automatically
- Flag prevents duplicate tab (correct)

**Multiple Tabs from Repeated Launches**:
- If user launches exe multiple times = multiple tabs is expected
- User controls this by not double-clicking multiple times
- System tray 'Open in Browser' available if tab is closed

**Conclusion**: Current behavior is correct by design. Closing as not a bug.

title: Implement Roadmap/Timeline gantt chart visualization
description:
Create a dedicated Roadmap/Timeline tab with gantt chart visualization for planning and tracking epics and high-level deliverables. This feature enables users to visualize project timelines, track epic progress, and manage milestones separately from sprint-level burndown tracking.

**Key Features:**
- Dedicated tab for roadmap view (separate from sprint burndown)
- Gantt chart showing epics/initiatives with start and end dates
- Configurable JIRA issue types (Epic, Initiative, Release, etc.)
- Flexible date field mapping (target dates, fixVersions, or fallback to created/resolution)
- Vertical milestone markers at configurable dates
- Handle ongoing work (no end date = extend to horizon)
- Separate JQL query configuration from main burndown query
- Color coding by issue type, status, or project
- Mobile-first responsive design

**Technical Approach:**
- Reuse existing field mapping system (similar to DORA/Flow metrics)
- Leverage SQLite persistence with separate roadmap query namespace
- Plotly Gantt chart visualization
- Follow established tab configuration pattern (TAB_CONFIG registry)
- ~8-12 days implementation effort

**Use Cases:**
- Product managers tracking epic delivery timelines
- Release planning with milestone markers
- Portfolio view of multiple initiatives
- Stakeholder communication with high-level roadmap
- Dependency visualization across epics

**Prerequisites:**
- JIRA epics or similar issue types with date fields (or use created/resolved as fallback)
- Optional: Custom fields for target start/end dates
- Existing burndown chart profile and JIRA connection
notes:
## Technical Analysis

### Architecture Overview

**Current System Structure:**
- **Tab System:** TAB_CONFIG registry in ui/tabs.py defines all tabs (currently 7 tabs)
- **Query Management:** data/query_manager.py handles profile-based queries with SQLite persistence
- **JIRA API:** data/jira_simple.py with field mapping support via field_mappings config
- **Database:** SQLite backend (profiles/burndown.db) with 12 tables
- **Visualization:** Plotly charts in visualization/ package
- **Tab Navigation:** Mobile + desktop responsive with dbc.Tabs component

### Roadmap/Timeline Requirements Analysis

**1. JIRA Data Requirements:**
- **Issue Types:** Configurable (Epic, Initiative, Release, etc.)
- **Date Fields:** 
  - Primary: Target Start/End dates (customfield_XXXXX)
  - Fallback: created/resolutiondate (standard fields)
  - Support: fixVersions.releaseDate for version-based roadmaps
- **Field Mapping:** Leverage existing field_mappings system (FR-006 through FR-010)
- **Query:** Separate JQL query distinct from current burndown query

**2. Data Model Considerations:**
- **Unlimited End Dates:** Handle NULL or ongoing items (no resolution date)
- **Visualization:** Gantt chart needs start date, end date (or current date as proxy)
- **Milestones:** Vertical lines at configurable dates (similar to deadline markers)
- **Time Range:** Calculate min/max dates from dataset + configurable padding

**3. UI/UX Design:**
- **New Tab:** Add to TAB_CONFIG with order=7 (after Weekly Data)
  - id: 'tab-roadmap' or 'tab-timeline'
  - icon: 'fa-calendar-alt' or 'fa-road'
  - requires_data: True
- **Query Configuration:** Dedicated settings for roadmap JQL query
- **Date Field Mapping:** UI to map issue type date fields (similar to DORA field mapping)
- **Milestone Configuration:** Input for milestone dates with labels

**4. Visualization Strategy:**
- **Library:** Plotly Gantt chart (plotly.figure_factory.create_gantt)
- **Alternative:** Custom Plotly.graph_objects with horizontal bars
- **Features Needed:**
  - Color coding by issue type or status
  - Hover info: issue key, summary, dates
  - Vertical milestone lines (similar to add_deadline_marker)
  - Today marker (vertical line showing current date)
  - Zoom/pan for long timelines
  - Ongoing items: extend to current date or future cutoff

**5. Data Flow Pattern:**
`
User configures roadmap query (JQL + issue types + date fields)
  ↓
Separate JIRA API call (fetch_jira_issues with roadmap config)
  ↓
Store in SQLite (separate table or query namespace)
  ↓
Transform to Gantt format (start_date, end_date, task_name)
  ↓
Render Plotly Gantt chart in tab-roadmap content
  ↓
Add milestone overlays (vertical lines)
`

### Implementation Approach

**Phase 1: Configuration & Data (3-4 days)**
- Add roadmap_config to app_settings.json:
  - roadmap_jql: str (JQL query for roadmap items)
  - roadmap_issue_types: List[str] (Epic, Initiative, etc.)
  - roadmap_start_field: str (customfield_XXXXX or 'created')
  - roadmap_end_field: str (customfield_XXXXX or 'resolutiondate')
  - roadmap_milestones: List[{date: str, label: str}]
- Update data/query_manager.py to support roadmap query type
- Create data/roadmap_fetcher.py for JIRA data retrieval
- Add SQLite table or use existing jira_issues with roadmap query_id

**Phase 2: Visualization (2-3 days)**
- Create visualization/roadmap_chart.py
- Implement create_roadmap_gantt_chart():
  - Transform JIRA issues to Gantt format
  - Handle unlimited end dates (use today or max_date)
  - Add milestone vertical lines
  - Color code by issue type/status
- Handle edge cases (single-day items, overlapping items)

**Phase 3: UI Integration (2-3 days)**
- Add tab to TAB_CONFIG in ui/tabs.py
- Create ui/roadmap_tab.py for layout
- Create callbacks/roadmap.py for data updates
- Add roadmap settings to settings panel (accordion or tab)
- Mobile-first responsive design

**Phase 4: Testing & Polish (1-2 days)**

- Integration tests for JIRA data fetch
- Edge case testing (no data, all ongoing, etc.)
- Performance testing (100+ items)

### Technical Challenges & Solutions

**Challenge 1: Unlimited End Dates**
- **Solution:** Use today + configurable horizon (e.g., 6 months) or max(all_end_dates) + buffer

**Challenge 2: Separate Query Management**
- **Solution:** Reuse existing query_manager.py pattern, add roadmap query type

**Challenge 3: Gantt Chart Performance**
- **Solution:** Limit to 200 items, provide filtering by issue type/project

**Challenge 4: Date Field Flexibility**
- **Solution:** Field mapping UI similar to DORA/Flow metrics (callbacks/field_mapping.py pattern)

### Files to Modify/Create

**New Files:**

### Dependencies

**Existing Patterns to Reuse:**
- Field mapping: callbacks/field_mapping.py, data/field_mapper.py
- Query management: data/query_manager.py
- Deadline markers: visualization/charts.py::add_deadline_marker()

**External Libraries:**

### Success Criteria

- [ ] User can configure separate JQL query for roadmap

2. **Apache Kafka JIRA:** Check if Epics have target start/end custom fields
3. **Field Detection:** Can field_detector.py auto-detect date fields in Epics?
4. **User Preferences:** Survey users on preferred name: Roadmap vs Timeline

### Estimated Effort

**Complexity:** Medium-High (requires coordination across multiple layers)
**Risk:** Low (reuses existing patterns extensively)



## Interactive Roadmap Requirements (User-Editable Gantt Chart)

### Updated Feature Scope

**CRITICAL CHANGE:** Roadmap must be fully interactive with drag-and-drop editing capabilities, NOT static Plotly visualization.

**User Interactions Required:**
1. **Drag Blocks Vertically:** Reorder items in timeline
2. **Drag Blocks Horizontally:** Change start/end dates
3. **Resize Blocks:** Adjust target start/end dates by dragging edges
4. **Edit Names:** Click to edit issue summary text inline
5. **Local Persistence:** All changes saved to SQLite, NEVER synced to JIRA
6. **Override Warning:** Re-fetching JIRA data will overwrite local changes

### Interactive Timeline Library Options

**Option 1: vis-timeline (Recommended)**
- **Library:** vis-timeline (formerly vis.js timeline)
- **npm:** vis-timeline (MIT license)
- **Features:** Full drag-and-drop, resize, edit, zoom, pan
- **Dash Integration:** Custom Dash component wrapper or iframe + clientside callbacks
- **Data Format:** JSON timeline items with start/end dates
- **Pros:** Battle-tested, feature-complete, great documentation
- **Cons:** Requires custom Dash component or iframe integration
- **Example:** https://visjs.github.io/vis-timeline/examples/

**Option 2: react-beautiful-dnd + Custom Timeline**
- **Library:** react-beautiful-dnd (Atlassian)
- **npm:** react-beautiful-dnd
- **Features:** Smooth drag-and-drop, accessibility
- **Dash Integration:** Create custom Dash component with React
- **Pros:** React-based (Dash uses React), smooth animations
- **Cons:** Requires custom timeline rendering logic
- **Complexity:** High (custom timeline implementation)

**Option 3: FullCalendar Timeline View**
- **Library:** FullCalendar (premium timeline addon)
- **License:** Commercial license required for timeline
- **Features:** Professional timeline with resource management
- **Dash Integration:** iframe or custom component
- **Pros:** Professional, feature-rich
- **Cons:** Paid license, heavyweight

**Option 4: dhtmlxGantt**
- **Library:** dhtmlxGantt
- **License:** GPL (free) or Commercial
- **Features:** Full gantt chart with dependencies, editing
- **Dash Integration:** iframe or custom component
- **Pros:** Purpose-built for gantt charts
- **Cons:** License complexity, large library

**RECOMMENDATION: vis-timeline (Option 1)**
- Open source (MIT)
- Perfect feature match (drag, resize, edit)
- Proven in production
- Integration: Custom Dash component or iframe + postMessage

### Integration Architecture: vis-timeline + Dash

**Approach A: Custom Dash Component (Recommended)**
- Create custom React component wrapping vis-timeline
- Package as Dash component library
- Full Dash integration with callbacks
- **Effort:** 3-4 days for component development
- **Reference:** dash-bootstrap-components pattern

**Approach B: iframe + postMessage (Faster)**
- Serve vis-timeline in iframe (separate HTML)
- Use postMessage for JS ↔ Dash communication
- Clientside callbacks to sync data
- **Effort:** 1-2 days for prototype
- **Trade-off:** Less elegant but faster to implement

**Approach C: Dash Mantine Components Timeline (Alternative)**
- **Library:** dash-mantine-components (has Timeline component)
- **Limitation:** Timeline is display-only, not drag-and-drop gantt
- **Verdict:** Not suitable for roadmap requirements

### Data Flow: Two-Layer Persistence

**Layer 1: JIRA Source of Truth (Read-Only)**
`
JIRA API → SQLite jira_issues table
- Original issue data from JIRA
- Fields: issue_key, summary, start_date, end_date, issue_type, status
- Re-fetch overwrites this layer
`

**Layer 2: Local Overrides (User Edits)**
`
User Edits → SQLite roadmap_overrides table
- Tracks local modifications
- Fields: issue_key, custom_summary, custom_start_date, custom_end_date, custom_order
- Persists across sessions
- NEVER synced to JIRA
`

**Merge Logic (Display):**
`python
def get_roadmap_items():
    jira_items = backend.get_roadmap_issues()  # From jira_issues
    overrides = backend.get_roadmap_overrides()  # From roadmap_overrides
    
    for item in jira_items:
        if item['key'] in overrides:
            # Apply local overrides
            item['summary'] = overrides[item['key']].get('custom_summary', item['summary'])
            item['start_date'] = overrides[item['key']].get('custom_start_date', item['start_date'])
            item['end_date'] = overrides[item['key']].get('custom_end_date', item['end_date'])
            item['order'] = overrides[item['key']].get('custom_order', item['order'])
    
    return sorted(jira_items, key=lambda x: x['order'])
`

### Database Schema (New Table)

`sql
CREATE TABLE roadmap_overrides (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    profile_id TEXT NOT NULL,
    query_id TEXT NOT NULL,
    issue_key TEXT NOT NULL,
    custom_summary TEXT,
    custom_start_date TEXT,  -- ISO8601 format
    custom_end_date TEXT,
    custom_order INTEGER,
    modified_at TEXT NOT NULL,
    UNIQUE(profile_id, query_id, issue_key)
);

CREATE INDEX idx_roadmap_overrides_lookup 
ON roadmap_overrides(profile_id, query_id);
`

### Clientside Callback Architecture

**Pattern:** Use clientside callbacks for real-time UI updates, server callbacks for persistence

`javascript
// Clientside: Handle drag events (instant UI feedback)
window.dash_clientside.roadmap = {
    onItemDrag: function(timelineEvents) {
        // Update UI immediately
        // Return new item positions for dcc.Store
        return {
            'dragging': true,
            'items': updatedItems
        };
    },
    
    onItemResize: function(timelineEvents) {
        // Update dates immediately
        return {
            'resizing': true,
            'items': updatedItems
        };
    }
};
`

`python
# Server: Persist changes to SQLite
@callback(
    Output('roadmap-save-status', 'data'),
    Input('roadmap-items-store', 'data'),
    prevent_initial_call=True
)
def save_roadmap_changes(items):
    backend.save_roadmap_overrides(items)
    return {'saved': True, 'timestamp': datetime.now()}
`

### Override Warning System

**UI Component:** Banner at top of roadmap tab
`python
dbc.Alert([
    html.I(className='fas fa-exclamation-triangle me-2'),
    'Local edits active. Re-fetching JIRA data will overwrite your changes.',
    dbc.Button('Clear Overrides', id='clear-overrides-btn', size='sm', className='ms-2')
], color='warning', id='roadmap-override-warning', dismissible=False)
`

**Behavior:**
- Show when oadmap_overrides table has records for active profile/query
- Hide when no overrides exist
- 'Clear Overrides' button deletes all overrides for current profile/query

### Technical Challenges & Solutions (Updated)

**Challenge 1: Dash ↔ JavaScript Integration**
- **Solution A (Recommended):** Custom Dash component wrapping vis-timeline
  - Create React component following dash-component-boilerplate
  - Package as dash-vis-timeline library
  - Full Dash callback integration
  - **Effort:** 3-4 days
  - **Reference:** https://github.com/plotly/dash-component-boilerplate

- **Solution B (Faster Prototype):** iframe + postMessage
  - Serve vis-timeline.html as static asset
  - Use dcc.Iframe to embed
  - Clientside callbacks + postMessage for communication
  - **Effort:** 1-2 days
  - **Trade-off:** Less elegant, harder to style consistently

**Challenge 2: Real-Time UI Updates Without Server Round-Trip**
- **Solution:** Clientside callbacks for drag/resize events
  - JavaScript handles immediate UI feedback
  - Debounced server callback for persistence (save after 1s idle)
  - Pattern: dcc.Store intermediate → debounce → server save

**Challenge 3: JIRA Re-Fetch Override Conflict**
- **Solution:** Three-way merge strategy
  - Fetch new JIRA data
  - Load local overrides
  - Detect conflicts (deleted issues, renamed issues)
  - Show conflict resolution modal with options:
    a) Keep local changes
    b) Discard local changes
    c) Merge (use JIRA data for new fields, keep local edits)

**Challenge 4: Performance with 100+ Timeline Items**
- **Solution:** vis-timeline built-in virtualization
  - Only renders visible items
  - Handles 1000+ items efficiently
  - Add filtering (by project, issue type, status)

### Files to Create/Modify (Updated)

### Estimated Effort (Revised)

## fixVersions Support (Additional Date Source)

JIRA fixVersions provide structured release planning data with built-in date fields:

**fixVersions Data Structure:**
- fixVersions.name: Release name (e.g., 'v2.1.0', 'Q1 2026')
- fixVersions.startDate: Planned release start date (ISO8601)
- fixVersions.releaseDate: Target release date (ISO8601)
- fixVersions.released: Boolean flag (completed releases)
- fixVersions.archived: Boolean flag (historical releases)

**Integration Strategy:**
1. Primary Data Source: Use fixVersions dates when available
2. Fallback Hierarchy:
   - fixVersions.startDate/releaseDate (preferred)
   - Custom target date fields (customfield_XXXXX)
   - Created/resolutionDate (last resort)

**Roadmap Display Logic:**
- Issue with fixVersions → Use fixVersion start/release dates as timeline block
- Multiple fixVersions → Show as separate timeline blocks OR merge date range
- No fixVersions → Fall back to custom fields or created/resolved dates

**Database Schema Update:**
Add to roadmap_overrides table:
- fix_version_name TEXT (track which version is overridden)
- original_start_date TEXT (preserve JIRA original for conflict detection)
- original_end_date TEXT (preserve JIRA original for conflict detection)

**UI Enhancements:**
- Display fixVersion badge on timeline blocks
- Filter by fixVersion (show only items in specific release)
- Color code by fixVersion (different releases = different colors)
- Release milestone markers (vertical lines at fixVersion.releaseDate)

**Example JIRA Query:**
`jql
project = MYPROJ AND fixVersion in unreleasedVersions() ORDER BY fixVersion ASC
`

**Benefits:**
- Aligns with JIRA's native release planning
- No custom field configuration needed
- Automatic release grouping
- Built-in release status (released/unreleased)

**Impact on Sub-Tasks:**
- Task 2 (Database): Add fixVersion fields to schema
- Task 3 (Data Layer): Implement fixVersion date extraction and fallback logic
- Task 4 (Integration): Display fixVersion badges on timeline items
- Task 5 (UI): Add fixVersion filter and release milestone configuration

title: Conflict Resolution: JIRA re-fetch with override handling
description:
Implement conflict resolution when re-fetching JIRA data with active local overrides.

**Scenarios:**
1. **New Issues:** Add to roadmap (no conflict)
2. **Deleted Issues:** Remove from JIRA, keep override as orphan or delete
3. **Modified Issues:** JIRA data changed, local override exists
4. **Renamed Issues:** Issue key unchanged but summary changed

**Conflict Detection:**
`python
def detect_conflicts(jira_issues, overrides) -> List[Conflict]:
    '''Compare JIRA data with local overrides'''
    conflicts = []
    for issue_key in overrides:
        if issue_key not in jira_issues:
            conflicts.append(Conflict('deleted', issue_key))
        elif jira_issues[issue_key].summary != overrides[issue_key].original_summary:
            conflicts.append(Conflict('modified', issue_key))
    return conflicts
`

**Resolution Modal:**
- Show list of conflicts
- Options per conflict:
  - Keep local changes
  - Use JIRA data
  - Delete override
- Batch action: Apply to all

**Files:**
- data/roadmap_conflict_resolver.py (new)
- ui/roadmap_conflict_modal.py (new)

notes:
Implementation details:

Problem: Windows Disk Cleanup or user manually deletes files from %TEMP%, breaking update state.

Solution: Graceful degradation with file existence checks.

Code location: app.py startup, in restore_pending_update() function.

Logic:
- Restore pending_update_path from database
- Check if Path(path_str).exists()
- If exists: Set VERSION_CHECK_RESULT status='READY' (downloaded, ready to install)
- If missing: Set VERSION_CHECK_RESULT status='AVAILABLE' (need to re-download)
- Clear stale database keys: backend.set_app_state('pending_update_path', None)
- Log warning but no error dialogs

Behavior matches industry standard (Chrome, Firefox): Missing download → fall back to 'download again' state.

title: Add system tray icon for background app control
description:
Implement system tray icon for console-free executable to provide user control and visibility.

REQUIREMENTS:

1. System Tray Icon:
   - Appears in Windows system tray when app runs
   - Uses app icon (assets/icon.ico)
   - Shows on hover: 'Burndown Chart - Running on http://127.0.0.1:8050'

2. Context Menu Actions:
   - 'Open in Browser' - Opens/focuses http://127.0.0.1:8050 in default browser
   - 'Quit' - Gracefully shuts down app (sys.exit(0))

3. Implementation Details:
   - Library: pystray (https://pypi.org/project/pystray/)
   - Add to requirements.in: pystray>=0.19.5
   - Tray icon runs in separate daemon thread
   - Must not block Dash/Waitress server
   - Icon file: assets/icon.ico (already exists for executable)

4. Files to Modify:
   - requirements.in - add pystray dependency
   - app.py - initialize tray icon when running as frozen executable
   - build/app.spec - ensure icon.ico is bundled (already is)

5. Code Structure:
   `python
   if getattr(sys, 'frozen', False):  # Only for executable
       import pystray
       from PIL import Image
       
       def on_open(icon, item):
           webbrowser.open('http://127.0.0.1:8050')
       
       def on_quit(icon, item):
           icon.stop()
           sys.exit(0)
       
       icon = pystray.Icon('burndown-chart',
           Image.open('assets/icon.ico'),
           'Burndown Chart',
           menu=pystray.Menu(
               pystray.MenuItem('Open in Browser', on_open),
               pystray.MenuItem('Quit', on_quit)
           ))
       
       # Run in separate thread
       threading.Thread(target=icon.run, daemon=True).start()
   `

6. Testing Checklist:
   - [ ] Tray icon appears when app starts
   - [ ] Hover shows app name and URL
   - [ ] 'Open in Browser' launches/focuses browser tab
   - [ ] 'Quit' cleanly shuts down app
   - [ ] Icon disappears when app exits
   - [ ] No tray icon when running 'python app.py' (source mode)
   - [ ] Works with update flow (old icon stops, new icon appears)

BENEFITS:
- User can always reopen browser if tab closed
- Clean way to quit without Task Manager
- Visibility that app is running
- Professional UX like mailhog, Docker Desktop, etc.

- Secondary: MTTR Cycle Time average (Bug: created -> resolutiondate)

- Add 'Waiting for Deployment' (if Bug->resolutiondate and Problem->fixVersions available)

- create_deployment_frequency_trend(): Dual traces (deployments + releases)
- Primary: operational tasks, Secondary: unique fixVersions
- MTTR trend: Single trace  replicate dual pattern

- incident_detected_at, incident_resolved_at labels
- Need: incident_created_at, new incident_resolved_at (rename old to incident_deployed_at)

title: Fix silent update failures and improve temp file management
description:
**Bug**: Update from v2.6.2 to v2.6.3 fails silently. Download succeeds, .bak file created, but update stops at copy phase. Root cause: stale temp directories from previous failed updates block new extractions.

**Root Cause Analysis**:
- Static folder name 'burndown_update_temp' causes conflicts
- Existing folders not cleaned before extraction
- Updater output went to /dev/null (no error visibility)
- Generic naming pattern risks collision with other apps

**Fixes Implemented**:
1. Unique extraction directories: burndown_chart_update_{uuid} (prevents conflicts)
2. Updater logging: Output to %TEMP%\burndown_chart_updater.log (diagnostic visibility)
3. Automatic cleanup: Remove orphaned folders >1hr old on app startup
4. Consistent naming: All temp resources use 'burndown_chart_*' namespace
5. Fail-fast: Abort if cleanup fails (defensive programming)

**Files Changed**:
- updater/updater.py: Unique extract dirs, defensive cleanup
- data/update_manager.py: Redirect updater output to log file
- app.py: Cleanup orphaned extraction directories
- docs/updater_architecture.md: Document troubleshooting steps

**Testing**:
- Manually delete temp folders → update succeeds
- Verify log creation: %TEMP%\burndown_chart_updater.log
- Check cleanup: burndown_chart_update_* folders removed after 1hr

**Impact**: Users won't need to manually clean temp folders. Failed updates self-heal on retry.

All fixes implemented and tested. Ready for next release (v2.6.4).

title: Refactor data/persistence/adapters.py (1888 lines → <500)
description:
Refactor data/persistence/adapters.py from 1888 lines to comply with 500-line architectural guideline.

## Current Analysis
**File**: data/persistence/adapters.py
**Size**: 1888 lines (3.8x over 500-line limit)
**Functions**: 20+ persistence adapter functions

## Initial Assessment
Contains multiple persistence domains:
1. **Helpers**: _get_file_lock, DateTimeEncoder class, convert_timestamps_to_strings, should_sync_jira
2. **App Settings**: save_app_settings, load_app_settings
3. **Project Data**: save_project_data, load_project_data, save_unified_project_data, load_unified_project_data
4. **Settings**: save_settings, load_settings
5. **Statistics**: save_statistics, save_statistics_from_csv_import, load_statistics
6. **Sample Data**: generate_realistic_sample_data, read_and_clean_data
7. **Scope**: get_project_statistics, get_project_scope, update_project_scope
8. **Migration**: _migrate_legacy_project_data

## Proposed Split Strategy
1. **data/persistence/adapters/** subdirectory:
   - core.py - Helper functions, DateTimeEncoder, file locks (< 200 lines)
   - app_settings.py - save_app_settings, load_app_settings (< 350 lines)
   - project_data.py - save_project_data, load_project_data, unified functions (< 450 lines)
   - settings.py - save_settings, load_settings (< 200 lines)
   - statistics.py - All statistics save/load functions (< 400 lines)
   - sample_data.py - generate_realistic_sample_data, read_and_clean_data (< 250 lines)
   - scope.py - get_project_statistics, get_project_scope, update_project_scope (< 150 lines)
   - migrations.py - _migrate_legacy_project_data (< 150 lines)
   
2. **data/persistence/adapters/__init__.py** - Export all public functions

## Tasks
1. Identify shared dependencies between adapter functions
2. Group by data domain (app settings, project data, statistics, etc.)
3. Split into 8 focused files (each < 500 lines)
4. Update 30+ import statements across codebase
5. Maintain backward compatibility
6. Run tests to verify persistence works

## Success Criteria
- All files < 500 lines (target: 150-450)
- Clear domain separation
- All imports updated
- All tests pass
- Zero errors from get_errors

title: Optimize toast message styling to reduce size and prevent header wrapping
description:
**Problem**: Toast message headers often wrap to 2 lines, making toasts unnecessarily large due to empty space and oversized text.

**Goals**:
- Reduce font size in toast messages (both header and body)
- Reduce unused empty space/padding inside toasts
- Increase toast width by ~20px to prevent header wrapping
- Keep position fixed at top-right corner of screen

**Reason**: Current toasts take up too much vertical space when headers wrap, reducing screen real estate and looking cluttered.

**Implementation**: Adjust CSS in prevent_credentials_popup.css or custom.css for .toast elements.
notes:
## Technical Analysis

### Current Implementation

#### 1. Toast Component Structure
- File: ui/toast_notifications.py (lines 24-132)
- Function: create_toast() - Creates dbc.Toast components
- Default minWidth: 280px (hardcoded inline style, line 131)
- Content structure: Icon + message wrapped in html.Div

#### 2. Toast Container Location
- File: ui/layout.py (lines 141-149)
- Container ID: 'app-notifications'
- Position: Fixed at top: 5px, right: 5px
- Width: 350px (container width)
- Z-index: 9999 (highest layer)

#### 3. Current CSS Styling
- File: assets/custom.css (lines 5867-5888)
- Toast header: padding: var(--space-3) = 1.5rem = 24px
- Toast body: padding: var(--space-3) = 1.5rem = 24px
- Toast header font: font-weight: var(--font-semibold) = 600
- Toast body font: font-size: var(--text-sm) = 0.875rem = 14px
- Border radius: var(--radius-lg) = 0.5rem = 8px
- Shadow: var(--shadow-lg)

#### 4. Design System Variables (custom.css lines 1-200)
- --space-3: 1.5rem (24px) - Current padding
- --space-2: 1rem (16px) - Smaller padding option
- --space-1: 0.5rem (8px) - Minimal padding option
- --text-sm: 0.875rem (14px) - Body text (already used)
- --text-xs: 0.75rem (12px) - Smaller text option
- --font-semibold: 600 - Current header weight
- --font-medium: 500 - Lighter weight option

### Proposed Changes (Non-Breaking)

#### 1. Reduce Padding
**Target**: .toast-header and .toast-body
- Change from: padding: var(--space-3) [24px]
- Change to: padding: var(--space-2) [16px] OR padding: var(--space-1) var(--space-2) [8px 16px]
- Impact: Reduces vertical space by ~16-32px per toast

#### 2. Reduce Font Sizes
**Target**: .toast-header
- Add: font-size: var(--text-sm) [14px] (currently inherits larger size)
- Keep font-weight: var(--font-semibold) for emphasis
**Target**: .toast-body (already 14px)
- Optional: font-size: var(--text-xs) [12px] for more compact body

#### 3. Increase Toast Width
**Target**: ui/toast_notifications.py line 131
- Change from: minWidth: '280px'
- Change to: minWidth: '300px' (~20px increase as requested)
**Alternative**: Adjust container width in ui/layout.py line 148
- Change from: width: '350px'
- Change to: width: '370px'

#### 4. Header Wrapping Prevention
- Increasing minWidth by 20px should reduce wrapping for most headers
- Alternative: Add CSS max-width and text-overflow: ellipsis for extremely long headers
- Keep position: fixed, top: 5px, right: 5px (as requested)

### Implementation Files
1. assets/custom.css (lines 5874-5888) - Padding and font size changes
2. ui/toast_notifications.py (line 131) - minWidth inline style
3. Optional: ui/layout.py (line 148) - Container width adjustment

### Risk Assessment
- **Low Risk**: CSS padding/font changes (easily reversible)
- **Very Low Risk**: Width adjustments (only affects toast container)
- **No Breaking Changes**: All existing toast calls continue to work
- **Backward Compatible**: Design system variables ensure consistency

title: Flow metrics not updating when status mappings changed
description:
When changing status mappings in Configure JIRA Mappings > Status tab (e.g., removing 'In Review' from Active statuses or 'Selected' from WIP statuses), Flow metrics do NOT update even after clicking 'Save Mappings', 'Update Data', or 'Force Refresh'.

REPRODUCTION:
1. Open Configure JIRA Mappings modal > Status tab
2. Remove a status from 'Active' or 'WIP' lists (e.g., remove 'In Review')
3. Click 'Save Mappings' (green toast confirms save)
4. Click 'Update Data' button
5. Check Flow Efficiency or Flow Load metric
6. ACTUAL: Metric value unchanged (e.g., Flow Load still 23)
7. EXPECTED: Metric recalculated with new mappings

TECHNICAL FINDINGS:
- Status mappings ARE saved correctly to database (verified)
- calculate_flow_efficiency() and calculate_flow_load() DO read from database dynamically (no hardcoding)
- ROOT CAUSE: Metrics cache optimization in data/metrics_calculator.py lines 124-147
- When metrics exist for historical weeks, system returns cached values WITHOUT checking if configuration changed
- New mappings never applied because recalculation is skipped

IMPACT:
- Critical UX bug: Users cannot adjust Flow metrics calculations
- Configuration changes appear to be ignored
- No way to see effect of status mapping changes without manual cache clearing

SOLUTION:
Option 1: Invalidate metrics cache when status mappings change (save_field_mappings callback)
Option 2: Add 'Recalculate Metrics' button that forces full recalculation ignoring cache
Option 3: Store config hash with each snapshot, recalculate if hash changed
notes:
COMPLETE FIX:

1. Root cause: In-memory snapshots cache not cleared on config save
   - Added clear_snapshots_cache() call after backend.delete_metrics()
   
2. UI reactivity: Metrics tabs didn't auto-update after save
   - Added metrics-refresh-trigger output to save_or_validate_mappings callback
   - Returns time.time() timestamp on successful save
   - Triggers Flow/DORA metrics callbacks to refresh immediately
   
RESULT: When user clicks 'Save Mappings':
1. Validates and saves config
2. Deletes metrics_data_points rows from database
3. Clears _snapshots_cache in-memory
4. Updates metrics-refresh-trigger store with timestamp
5. Flow/DORA tabs immediately show 'No Metrics' state (empty state component)
6. User clicks 'Update Data' → recalculates with new config → displays updated metrics

BEHAVIOR MATCHES: Same UX as 'Update Data' button - metrics tabs react immediately.
close_reason: Fixed: Flow metrics now update immediately when status mappings saved. Root cause: in-memory snapshots cache not cleared. Solution: Added clear_snapshots_cache() calls in field_mapping.py, Force Refresh, and metrics calculation. UI refresh trigger added via metrics-refresh-trigger store.
